It is characterized by its distinctive, shield-shaped fronds that are typically thick and leathery, providing structural support and protection. The plant is native to the humid Andean cloud forests of South America, particularly in regions of Peru and Bolivia. It thrives in shaded, moist environments and is often found growing on rocky substrates or in forest understories. Due to its limited distribution and specific habitat requirements, it is considered a rare and ecologically significant species.
